article.title: Photon motion in Kerr-de Sitter spacetimes

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the shaded regions in the (m, q)-plane represent for the latitudinal motion of photons?
choices: Regions where the latitudinal motion is allowed.
Regions where the latitudinal motion is forbidden.
Regions where spherical photon orbits exist.
Regions where the latitudinal motion is unstable.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the full and dashed curves represent in these plots?

multiple_choice_question.text: What determines the extremal values Xmin(−) and Xmax(+) of the potentials Xθ\n±(m; q, y, a) in the motion constant plane (X − q)?
choices: The intersection of a line q = const. < 0 with the border curves q1(X) and q2(X; y, a).
The intersection of a line X = const. with the curves Xθ\n±(m; q, y, a).

The local extrema of the functions q

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the separating surfaces in these parameter spaces divide the parameter spaces (q − X − y) and (q − X − a) into?
choices: Sub-spaces corresponding to stable (above) and unstable (beneath) photon orbits.
Sub-spaces corresponding to prograde (above) and retrograde (beneath) photon orbits.
Sub-spaces corresponding to allowed (above) and forbidden (beneath) values of kinetic constants q, X.
Sub-spaces corresponding to black hole (above) and naked singularity (beneath) spacetimes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do these characteristic functions a²(r) primarily determine?
choices: The behavior of the effective potentials X±(r; q, y, a).
The radii of spherical photon orbits.
The reality regions of the functions X±(r; q, y, a).
The behavior of the characteristic functions y(r; a²).

multiple_choice_question.text: What do these graphs of characteristic functions y(r; a²) help us understand?
choices: The stability of spherical photon orbits.
The allowed regions for the latitudinal motion of photons.
The behavior of the effective potentials X±(r; q, y, a) in different regions of the parameter plane (a² − y).
The orientation of spherical photon orbits.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the bold grey line representing the function y(ex(ex)+)-(ex(ex)−)2(a²) in this plot?
choices: It separates spacetimes with stable (above) and unstable (below) spherical photon orbits.
It separates spacetimes with divergent (above) and restricted (below) repulsive barrier of photon motion.
It separates spacetimes with both prograde and retrograde spherical photon orbits from those with only retrograde spherical photon orbits.
It separates black hole spacetimes (above) from naked singularity spacetimes (below).

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the grey vertical bars represent in these plots of characteristic functions?
choices: The event horizons.
The static radius.
The radii of spherical photon orbits.
The boundaries of the ergosphere.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the intersection of the full and dashed curves in Fig. 9(f) represent?
choices: The critical value of y for which the local minima of qex(r; y, a²) convert into local maxima.
The value of y for which the two polar spherical orbits coalesce.
The value of y for which the repulsive barrier becomes impermeable for photons with any impact parameter X.
The value of y for which the local extrema of qex(r; y, a²) have coalesced into an inflection point.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the shaded regions in these plots of effective potentials X±(r; q, y, a) represent?
choices: Regions where the radial motion of photons is forbidden.
Regions where spherical photon orbits exist.
Regions where the radial motion of photons is unstable.
Regions where the photons have negative energy (E < 0).
